sections.text:
## Summary / Goal  
We will add a lightweight “Bypass rate” panel to the Sales_Accelerator manager (Sales Ops) dashboard to help leaders detect workflow adoption drift. The panel will compute and display bypass rate and underlying counts using existing bypass event data already available in the analytics warehouse—no new product instrumentation, event schemas, or backend write paths required.

## User Experience / UI  
The panel will live alongside existing manager dashboard metrics and include: (1) an overall bypass rate, (2) bypassed vs. total eligible counts, and (3) a simple segmentation table or grouped bars by **workflow** (best-next-action, forecast updates, risk alerts) and **team**. A date-range selector will support **Last 7 days** and **Last 30 days** (default to last 7) and will apply consistently across the panel. Hover/tooltips will define “bypass” and clarify denominator logic (e.g., “eligible workflow prompts/actions”).

## Data & Computation  
We will source data from the existing warehouse bypass events and the corresponding “eligible/served” events that form the denominator (as already modeled today). The query will aggregate by `workflow`, `team_id` (or team name via existing dimension tables), and date bucket constrained by the selected range, returning `bypass_count`, `eligible_count`, and `bypass_rate = bypass_count / eligible_count`. The application will call a single read-only analytics endpoint (or reuse the dashboard’s existing query layer) and cache results at the dashboard level to avoid repeated warehouse hits while users switch segments.

## Rollout / Guardrails  
We will ship behind a feature flag for manager dashboards, validating correctness by reconciling a sample of teams/workflows against known warehouse totals. Edge cases include missing team attribution, sparse data (show “Insufficient data” when denominator is below a threshold), and partial workflow coverage (hide workflow rows with zero eligible events). Success will be measured by dashboard engagement with the panel and reduced time-to-detection for high bypass-rate teams, without any new instrumentation work.
